Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Spectroscopic Ellipsometry of Transition Metal Silicides
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical: This GOALI project is to study optical properties of transition metals and related intermetallic compounds, especially silicides. Metal and intermetallic compound films are grown on silicon and silicon oxide using physical vapor deposition at IBM. Samples are annealed to encourage grain growth, intermetallic reactions, and agglomeration (Ostwald ripening). The complex dielectric functions of the thin film materials are investigated using spectroscopic ellipsometry over a wide spectral range from the far infrared to the vacuum ultraviolet. Optical measurements are combined with semiconductor metrology techniques, particularly x-ray measurements and atomic force microscopy, to understand the film properties, intermetallic formation, and evolution of the films during materials and device processing.
Non-technical: The project addresses basic research issues in a topical area of materials science with high technological relevance. Low-resistance contacts to nanoelectronic devices require ultrathin Ohmic metal-semiconductor junctions with superior chemical, physical, and thermal stabilities. Ellipsometry allows non-contact investigations of the properties of thin metal films, intermetallic formation, and materials evolution during processing. Graduate and undergraduate students, including those in under-represented groups, will be trained for ellipsometry, metrology, semiconductor processing, and device fabrication, and learn about materials physics in industry. Well-designed capstone design projects for senior undergraduate students are an important component of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Accurate and rapid thickness measurements are an essential component of advanced manufacturing, especially in the semiconductor industry. For example, a modern processor (for a cell phone or laptop computer) contains about 75 photolayers. About 40 of these are structural layers, where a physical layer (oxide, semiconductor, or metal) is deposited or removed. Therefore, a typical semiconductor manufacturing process flow contains about 100 thickness measurements. Most of these measurements are performed using an optical interference technique called spectroscopic ellipsometry. To be effective, this technique requires precise knowledge of the optical constants (refractive index, absorption coefficient) of each material involved in the measurement. Corporations also rely on a trained workforce skilled in the art of thickness measurements. The outcomes of this project were two-fold:

First, the project resulted in accurate optical constants of nickel-platinum alloys (and their reaction products with silicon, called silicides), which are used for low-resistance electrical contacts to complementary metal oxide semiconductor transistors. Precise thickness measurements of these contact layers are now possible. The data were published in journal articles and on the PI’s web site at New Mexico State University. To be realistic, the materials used in this research were provided by the industrial partners in this GOALI project. The PI also wrote a chapter in a book on nanotechnology how to implement these optical constants for measurements in advanced nano-manufacturing. In addition, the project also provided optical constants for other materials: Thin layers of strontium titanate grown on silicon using liquid deposition techniques, lanthanum aluminate, magnesium aluminate (spinel), iron pyrite for solar cell applications, cobalt oxide spinel, strontium titanate doped with aluminum or lanthanum impurities, niobium dioxide, nickel oxide. The project also studied the nature of the electronic bond in nickel-platinum alloys and other classes of materials (especially complex oxides), to provide a more profound understanding of materials containing d- and f-electrons.

Second, to provide a workforce trained in the art of accurate thickness measurements for American manufacturers, the project placed much emphasis on training students of various levels in optical properties of materials and their applications for thickness measurements. The PI developed three new courses for the NMSU Physics Department, on semiconductor materials and processing, optical properties of materials, and elements of x-ray diffraction. One undergraduate student enrolled in these courses was placed in an internship with a semiconductor manufacturer in Rio Rancho, NM. One Ph.D. student supported by this grant received advanced training in ellipsometry, materials science, scientific communication, and managing research teams. She joined a semiconductor manufacturing company in Portland, OR, as a photolithography engineer. Two MS students supported by the project found positions with an Air Force contractor and Los Alamos National Lab, respectively. Thirteen undergraduate students (including six women and six underrepresented minorities) received advanced training in ellipsometry and materials science. Seven of these undergraduates went on to graduate school (including one who went to Harvard), two are now employed by STEM companies, and four are making good progress towards their undergraduate degrees. All of the undergraduates received training in scientific communication and networking by presenting talks and posters at regional and national scientific conferences. All are (or will be) coauthors on peer-reviewed journal articles written about their research.
